On March 11, the student body will have a chance to vote for their next
Young Trustee.
The importance of
making a responsible choice now is
paramount, for, once the Young Trustee
is elected, he or she operates in a setting
which is farther removed from student
scrutiny and feedback than that of any
other elective position. The person chosen
for such a post must be of a different
caliber altogether than that of the average
student politician. Fortunately for us all,
such a candidate exists.
Marshal Salant, though he has had
some involvement in student politics, has
managed to remain remarkably unsullied
by the experience. While he was on the
Student Council, Salant was always a
breath of fresh air amid the general
flatulence, refusing to succumb to the
perennial back-biting, and consistently
keeping his head free from the usual
delusions of grandeur.
Last year's Spring Fair ran like a
Swiss watch, and Salant deserves no small
part of the credit. When his performance
on such a major task is compared with
some of the other candidates' "handling"
of much smaller jobs, Salant begins to
emerge from the pack. Couple this with
his successful stint as a housemaster, and
it becomes clear that Marshal is qualified
to handle a wide spectrum of responsibility. It is no accident that he is assistant to
Dean Hall--a position which requires

ability, not ambition.
Most importantly, Salant is a man
possessed of an all-too-rare philosophy
concerning elected office. He sees winning a race not as a victory in some
popularity contest, but rather as the
taking on of a serious responsibility. Even
a short talk with the man reveals his
clarity of thought and
firm grasp of
hard realities. Marshal cares nothing for
personal vendettas, petty aggrandizement,
or any of the other activities which seem
to occupy the time of so many of our
Kampus Kingpins. Astounding as it may
be, his sense of satisfaction seems to stem
from doing a difficult job well, and seeing
that the people who elect him are well
served.
Look...the men of the Board of
Trustees are not amateurs—this is the Big
League now. They don't want another
pint-sized politician, and if they get one,
he—and we--will simply be ignored.
At least some of the contempt
which the Administration feels toward
undergraduates stems from the churlish
quality of the BMOC's we have elected to
deal with them, and Marshal's election
would be a first step toward turning this
sorry situation around. It must be clear
by this late date that Mo're. Of The Same
is definitely not what this student body
needs on the Board of Trustees. Luckily,
Marshal Salant means business, not
business-as-usual.

On March 11, the student body will have a chance to vote for their next
Young Trustee.
The importance of
making a responsible choice now is
paramount, for, once the Young Trustee
is elected, he or she operates in a setting
which is farther removed from student
scrutiny and feedback than that of any
other elective position. The person chosen
for such a post must be of a different
caliber altogether than that of the average
student politician. Fortunately for us all,
such a candidate exists.
Marshal Salant, though he has had
some involvement in student politics, has
managed to remain remarkably unsullied
by the experience. While he was on the
Student Council, Salant was always a
breath of fresh air amid the general
flatulence, refusing to succumb to the
perennial back-biting, and consistently
keeping his head free from the usual
delusions of grandeur.
Last year's Spring Fair ran like a
Swiss watch, and Salant deserves no small
part of the credit. When his performance
on such a major task is compared with
some of the other candidates' "handling"
of much smaller jobs, Salant begins to
emerge from the pack. Couple this with
his successful stint as a housemaster, and
it becomes clear that Marshal is qualified
to handle a wide spectrum of responsibility. It is no accident that he is assistant to
Dean Hall--a position which requires

ability, not ambition.
Most importantly, Salant is a man
possessed of an all-too-rare philosophy
concerning elected office. He sees winning a race not as a victory in some
popularity contest, but rather as the
taking on of a serious responsibility. Even
a short talk with the man reveals his
clarity of thought and
firm grasp of
hard realities. Marshal cares nothing for
personal vendettas, petty aggrandizement,
or any of the other activities which seem
to occupy the time of so many of our
Kampus Kingpins. Astounding as it may
be, his sense of satisfaction seems to stem
from doing a difficult job well, and seeing
that the people who elect him are well
served.
Look...the men of the Board of
Trustees are not amateurs—this is the Big
League now. They don't want another
pint-sized politician, and if they get one,
he—and we--will simply be ignored.
At least some of the contempt
which the Administration feels toward
undergraduates stems from the churlish
quality of the BMOC's we have elected to
deal with them, and Marshal's election
would be a first step toward turning this
sorry situation around. It must be clear
by this late date that Mo're. Of The Same
is definitely not what this student body
needs on the Board of Trustees. Luckily,
Marshal Salant means business, not
business-as-usual.
